text:
For me, one of life’s more frustrating interactions
is when I’m mid sentence and somebody cuts
me off.
They jump right in and interrupt.

And if you interrupt back, you find yourself
in a circle of constant interruption.
So, why do people interrupt you?

Now some reasons people interrupt are more
straightforward –

Some could be overtaken by excitement, and
blurt out the response they’ve already formed
a little too soon.

Other people interrupt as a power move to
seem more influential and as a result, the

people who they cut off are rated as less
influential.
If this happens to you, just keep talking.

But there are other reasons people interrupt
that we don’t fully understand.
Yet.

The thing is, conversations are really complicated
because we have to time this precise back
and forth with others.

In a normal conversation, we take one fifth
of a second to reply, which is like half a
blink.
Anything shorter than that and you’re interrupting.
Any longer, and there’s an awkward pause.

So to better understand what brain magic goes
into a conversation, and where it can go wrong,
researchers have turned to… mice.

Not just any rodent, but a singing mouse native
to the Costa Rican cloud forest.

They perform long and complex high-speed songs
that mimic the pace and back-and-forth of
human conversation.

Even though you might look at this little
guy and think, he looks just like my coworker

who always interrupts me, it turns out they’re
actually pros at taking turns when they sing.
They’re very polite!

Somehow, they can coordinate their back and
forth conversations with split second precision.
Just like humans.
(Theoretically!)

In a new study with the mice, researchers
identified an area of the brain called the

OMC that acts kinda like an orchestra conductor
– it coordinates this back and forth precision
of their communication.
“So I know what it's your turn you go.

And when it's my turn, I with almost no delay
can snap in”

So when researchers stimulated the OMC, the
mouse flexed its vocal muscles.

And when they slowed down the areas activity
by mildly cooling it, the mouse took longer
to reach the end of its song.

Then, when the area was inactivated by a drug,
the mice could still sing, but they sang over
each other.
You could say they interrupted.

And now
“We’re trying to find out where is it

in people where there's a kind of spark that
allows for conversational exchanges to be

planned and then quickly executed in the same
way as these mice”

Of course humans are more complicated, but
the little mice can show how the brain generates
speech and conducts conversation.

This helps us understand how speech is affected
in people suffering a stroke, or communication
differences in people with autism.

Now, remember what I said about the speed
of conversations back in the human world?

Normally we reply in half the time it takes
you to blink – anything shorter, you interrupt.
Longer and there’s a pause.

But these awkward pauses – even though they’re
memorable – are pretty uncommon in all of

the fluid conversations that we’re having
everyday.

We often have in mind our response to what
the other person is saying before they even
finish speaking.

And we squeeze our responses into these tiny
time frames.

So while you may find someone interrupting
you rude or annoying, just take a second,

please, to consider the amazing skills that
go into our everyday conversation.

Your brain is trying very hard and it’s
doing a pretty good job.

It’s kind of amazing that we don’t cut
each other off more frequently.
